facts.text: Sixteen petitions under Article 32 challenging the legality of surcharge imposed on income under Finance Acts of 1942, 1943, 1944 and 1945.

anchor.surface_text: These are sixteen petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the legality of the imposition of surcharge imposed on the income of the assessees under the Finance Acts of 1942, 1943, 1944 and 1945.

facts.text: Assessment relates to four assessment years 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45 and 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment relates to four assessment years 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45 and 1945-46.

facts.text: Petitioners are four partners of a firm named Mohammedaly Sarafaly Co., Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are four partners of a firm named Mohammedaly Sarafaly Co., Madras, which was carrying on business in hardware, stocks, shares, etc.

facts.text: Firm carried on business in hardware, stocks, shares, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Mohammedaly Sarafaly Co., Madras, which was carrying on business in hardware, stocks, shares, etc.

facts.text: For assessment years 1942-43 to 1945-46, firm treated as registered firm under Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1942-43 to 1945-46 this firm was treated as a registered firm under the Indian Income-tax Act and therefore the partners were assessed

facts.text: Partners assessed on their respective shares of profits from the business of the firm.

anchor.surface_text: under the Indian Income-tax Act and therefore the partners were assessed on their respective shares of the profits from the business of the firm.

facts.text: All assessments completed before 1949.

anchor.surface_text: All assessments were companypleted before 1949 and total income

facts.text: Total income for the four years was about Rs. 29,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: before 1949 and total income for the purpose of assessment for those four years was about Rs. 29,00,000.

facts.text: In 1955, petitioners made voluntary disclosure of income which had escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955 the petitioners under a Voluntary Disclosure Scheme with regard to profits which had escaped assessment made a disclosure of their income

facts.text: Proceedings taken under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act following disclosure.

anchor.surface_text: made a disclosure of their income and proceedings were taken under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Reassessment on all four partners in April 1959.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of April, 1959, there was a reassessment on all the four partners

facts.text: Total income for four years after reassessment about Rs. 35 lakhs, including Rs. 29 lakhs already assessed.

anchor.surface_text: and the total income for the four assessment years thus came to about Rs. 35 lakhs which included Rs. 29 lakhs already assessed.

facts.text: Income-tax, super-tax, and surcharge levied on reassessed income.

anchor.surface_text: On that income, income-tax, super-tax, and surcharge were levied.

facts.text: Surcharge levied was Rs. 3,82,791.

anchor.surface_text: The surcharge, according to the petition was Rs. 3,82,791.

facts.text: Petitioners challenge surcharge as without authority of law, Federal Legislature incompetent to levy surcharge.

anchor.surface_text: It is this surcharge which is impugned as being, without the authority of law inasmuch as the then Federal Legislature, it is submitted, was number companypetent to levy the surcharge.

facts.text: Provision for surcharge made under s. 8(1) of Finance Act, 1942 (Act XII of 1942).

anchor.surface_text: Provision for surcharge was made under s. 8 1  of the Finance Act, 1942  Act XII of 1942 . This section may number be quoted- Section 8 1  Subject to

facts.text: S. 8(1)(a) Finance Act 1942: income-tax for year beginning 1st April 1942 charged at rates in Part I Schedule II increased with surcharge for Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 1  Subject to the provisions of sub-sections  2  and  3 ,-  a  income-tax for the year beginning on the 1st day of April, 1942, shall be charged at the rates specified in Part I of Schedule II increased in the cases to which subparagraph  b  of paragraph A and paragraph B of that part apply with a sur- charge for the purposes of the Central Government at the rate specified therein in respect of each such rate of income-tax,

facts.text: Similar provisions in Finance Acts of 1943, 1944, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: under the Finance Acts of 1942, 1943, 1944 and 1945.

facts.text: Petitioners submit Federal Legislature had power under GOI Act 1935 s.138(1) to impose surcharge only for Federal purposes.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that according to this section the power of the Federal Legislature to impose a surcharge was only for Federal purposes

facts.text: Surcharge levied for purposes of Central Government, not Federal purposes, per petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: that by s. 8 1  of the Finance Act, 1942, and similar provisions in the other Finance Acts of three following years, the surcharge had been levied for the purposes of the Central Government and that the terms the purposes of the Central Government and for Federal purposes were number the same

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KAPUR, J. on March 22, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-These are sixteen petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging

facts.text: Petitions Nos. 140 and 177 to 191 of 1959 in Original Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petitions Nos. 140 and 177 to 191 of 1959. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Court holds petitioners' argument that Federal Legislature lacked power fallacious.

anchor.surface_text: This argument, in our opinion, is wholly fallacious.

facts.text: Petitions dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Federal Legislature had power to legislate on taxes on income under item 54 List I Seventh Schedule GOI Act 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Legislature therefore had the power to legislate in regard to any subject companytained in List I and item 54 relating to taxes on income was in that List.

issues.text: Whether the imposition of surcharge imposed on the income of the assessees under the Finance Acts of 1942, 1943, 1944 and 1945 is legal?

anchor.surface_text: Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the legality of the imposition of surcharge imposed on the income of the assessees under the Finance Acts of 1942, 1943, 1944 and 1945. The assessment relates to four assessment years 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45 and 1945-46. The petitioners are four partners of a firm

issues.text: Whether the Federal Legislature had power under the Government of India Act, 1935 to impose a surcharge for the purposes of the Central Government?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that the Federal Legislature had numberpower under the Government of India Act, 1935, 25 and 26 Geo V, Ch. 42 , to impose a surcharge for the purposes of the Central Government. The legislative power of the Federal Legislature was given in s. 100 of the Government of India Act, 1935, and the power to tax income was companytained in item 4 of List I of the Seventh Schedule which was as follows

issues.text: Whether the power of the Federal Legislature to impose a surcharge was only for Federal purposes and whether the surcharge had been levied for the purposes of the Central Government such that the terms differ?

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that according to this section the power of the Federal Legislature to impose a surcharge was only for Federal purposes that by s. 8 1  of the Finance Act, 1942, and similar provisions in the other Finance Acts of three following years, the surcharge had been levied for the purposes of the Central Government and that the terms the purposes of the Central Government and for Federal purposes were number the same but were two different companycepts.

issues.text: Whether the power under item 4 (taxes on income) of List I howsoever wide is subject to the limitation contained in s. 138(1) proviso (b) of the Government of India Act, 1935?

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Legislature therefore had the power to legislate in regard to any subject companytained in List I and item 54 relating to taxes on income was in that List. It has been held that the items have to be given the widest possible amplitude. But it was submitted that the power under item 54 howsoever wide it may be is subject to the limitation companytained in s. 138 1 , proviso b .
